Feature: Are there specific vocabularies for hunting or use in the presence of avoidance kin?
Is there ritual speech?
Does the ritual speech involve parallellisms, dual symbolic categories?
Is the ritual language known by everyone (or just by traditional leaders)?
Comment: Some of the words are from other dialects, or from an older variety of the language

Feature: Are there ritual songs?
Comment: When they take down the rice (of last year; that is in the rumah adat), they sing a song Tena Lau Kese, "A boat that is sailing".

Feature: Are there ritual dances?
Comment: Kong gitong

Feature: Is the language of the ritual songs a language you understand?
Comment: Some songs are in a different language (see next question's notes). Some songs are in an old version of Hewa that most people don't understand. But there are also songs in Hewa: Bau Bala is a Hewa song in Hewa.

Feature: Is the language of the ritual songs a foreign language?
Comment: Songs with words from Boru (if Boru is a different language). An example is recorded of a song in Boru Kedang. This song is sung when treading the rice after harvest.The song Tena Lau Kese (10.4) is in the Mohang language.

Feature: Do women and men dance together?
Comment: 4 men and 6 women

Feature: Are there traditional ceremonies where men and women must be separated?
Comment: sakalele: male's dance, lusi lerang: women's dance

Feature: Is there a ceremony relating to planting/harvesting?
Comment: Kebek bakur: after harvesting, pleba watar: after harvesting corn

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive in boats?
Comment: Some arrived in boats, some came from Boru, Lamaholot or Sika, and some came out of the ground. The Hewa ancestors are 2 kings: one married with a Maumere woman (in Muhang) and one went to Larantuka, travelling across the mountains, but never quite got there and stayed in Hewa. Muhang was used as a language before, but now it's gone from Hewa.

Feature: Does sacrifice involve feeding of ancestors?
Is there/are  there (a) ritual place(s)?
Comment: the rumah adat

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive as sea animals? (shark, crocodile, turtle, dolphin)
Is there a myth about the origin of the people?
Comment: ancestors who came out of the ground

Feature: Are there traditional religious leaders or specialists?
Comment: catholic pastor

Feature: Are there traditional drinks, or stimulants?
Comment: arak, tuak, sirih pinang

Feature: Is there a traditional sacrifice place?
Are there rituals around birth?
Comment: Traditional midwife = molan. Baby must stay inside the house for 5 days. This period is referred to as Lohor dedi.

Feature: Are there rituals around death?
Comment: Named Agoan (check recording)

Feature: Are there seasonal rituals apart from planting and harvesting, for example is there a ritual to ask for rain? Or other rituals?
Comment: ri': after harvest of the rice in the garden, kebek bakur: after harvest of the rice in the rumah adat; pleba watar: at the harvest of the corn

Feature: Do women traditionally weave?
Is there traditional pottery?
Are there moko?
Is it allowed to exchange the moko?
Are there people who make new moko?
Are there traditional music instruments?
Comment: gong, gendang: are played when the men are dancing

Feature: Are there particular traditional music styles?
Do people use body paint or tattoo?
Were teeth traditionally filed? (i.e. made shorter with a file)
Are there typical traditional haircuts?
Traditional piercings?
Comment: only ears

Feature: Are feathers or beads used as adornments?
Comment: chicken feathers are used in men's headpiece

Feature: Is there traditional jewelry?
Is there special adornment used in rituals or ceremonies?
Comment: men wear a kalambali (=headpiece) made from lontar leaf and chicken feathers, women wear a headpiece made of wool, their hair in a konde and a comb in between the head and the konde.

Feature: Is spatial organization divided into primary and secondary type?
Comment: east: wali, west: ripa; south: lau, north: reta

Feature: Are there conceptual connections between spatial directions such as E+S / W + N with male/female, or with day/night, or with right/left?
Do adults in this village typically speak more than one local language?
Comment: Lamaholot, B Indonesia (teachers or students that come home)

Feature: Do children typically speak more than one local language?
Comment: B Indonesia, Sika, Hewa

Feature: Is it common in this village that husband and wife have different languages?
Comment: It does occur but it is more common to have Hewa-Hewa marriages

Feature: Does a wife learn to speak the language of her husband?
Comment: If the wife is not Hewa she may learn Hewa but it is not necessary

Feature: Does a husband learn to speak the language of his wife?
Comment: If the husband is not Hewa he may learn Hewa but it is not necessary

Feature: Do they communicate with a third language?
Do people traditionally hunt?
Do people traditionally fish in the sea?
Do people traditionally have animal husbandry?
Comment: pig, goat, chicken, duck

Feature: Do people traditionally have agriculture?
Intensity of cultivation?
Major crops?
Are there clans?
Comment: Hewa has 27 clans; including: Liwu, Boru, Rotan, Soge, Ipir, Widin, Uran, Tapun, Kei, Pu'e, Maau, Liwu Maran, Soge Getei, Liwu Getei, Liwi Kur, Lewuk.

Feature: Are there moieties?
Is there a concept of 'house' (uma/rumah) that equals a descent group?
Are clans matrilineal
Are clans, subclans or lineages ranked
Comment: Widin are autochtonous, the original kings, they are the most important. Followed by the Soge. The remaining 24 clans are in the middle. The Tapun are the lowest in rank. They are the newcomers, the smallest group, and considered not much fun to talk to.

Feature: Does every clan speak their own language?
Is real property (land) inherited?
Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Comment: The Widin clan.

Feature: Are there inheritance rules?
Comment: everything goes to (eldest) son

Feature: Is land inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is land inheritance patrilineal (sons)?
Is moveable property inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is moveable property inheritance patrilineal?
Do all children inherit, sons and daughters alike?
Do all children inherit, with daughters receiving less?
Comment: It may happen but only if the son feels pity for his sister(s).

Feature: Can newcomers aquire land or gardens?
Comment: They buy from the owner.

Feature: At what age should young people get married?
Comment: 20-30 men (most around 24); 16-28 women (most around 18)

Feature: Are there marriage rules â€“ specify in notes field
Comment: 1. Certain clans do not marry each other: Widin-Soge is forbidden, Liwu-Plu'e is forbidden, Kei-Ipir is forbidden. 2. Marriage between cousins is always forbidden.

Feature: Is there gift exchange between bride's and groom's sides?
Comment: sirih pinang, tembako kasar, beras, ayam bakar, arak 1 bottle, 1 male goat

Feature: Is there bride service?
Transfer of residence at marriage?
Comment: Wife moves to husband's group only if the bridewealth is paid, otherwise the husband moves into the wife's group until it is paid.

Feature: Marital residence with kin?
Are traditional marriages obligatorily exogamous?
If mother dies, who raises the children?
Possible Values: 12:Father and his family.;10:Father and/or his family;11:Mother and/or her family

Feature: Does a man typically marry a woman of his mother's subclan?
Does a woman typicaly marry a man of her fatherâ€™s subclan?
Are there locality-based restrictions on marriage
Was polygamy permitted
Was polyandry permitted?
Is bridewealth paid by the groom's side to the bride's side
Comment: Ivory; if that is not available, then money

Feature: Is dowry paid by the bride's side to the groom's side
Comment: a ring, clothes for the wedding

Feature: Are villages the typical settlement pattern?
Are dispersed solitary family homesteads the typical settlement pattern?
Comment: Until the 1970's the people of Hewa lived in 8 different places. Now there are still 4 groups living elsewhere outside the village.

Feature: Are settlements permanent?
Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related women
Mean size of local communities?
Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related men?
Are villages/hamlets (traditionally) located on hill tops?
Comment: they can be in the mountains but not necessarily on hilltops

Feature: Are villages/hamlets (tradtionally) located on the shore?
Comment: They can be on the shore but this is not necessary.

Feature: Do villages have places or spaces for gatherings?
Comment: kantor desa, church

Feature: Shape of (traditional) houses?
Floor level of traditional houses?
Shape of roof of traditional houses?
Is there an attic or loft in a traditional house?
Do leaders come from particular lineages?
Are leaders non-hereditary?
Are there groups with whom traditional relations are forbidden?
Are there groups with whom there has been war?
Comment: There was a guerilla war against the Japanese. The Dua Toru made the guns. There have also been wars with the Lewo Ingo about land rights. In these fights, Koa Boru from Hewa was the hero.

Feature: Is there an opposition between people of the interior and people of the shore?
Comment: Original Hewa are the Ketan from the coast. There are differences in appearances and in the ceremonies of the coast and those inland. On the coast, they keep all the ceremonies, whereas not all of them are kept inland. On the coast, special groups have special tasks, e.g.Boru Dera are the cutters of meat, the Lotar and Ona are the people who serve the food.

Feature: Are there female community/clan leaders
Are there menâ€™s houses
Are there (traditional)   rulers/kings?
Comment: the Widin clan derives from the traditional ancestor king.

Feature: Are there slaves?
Is there a concept for both ruler and foreigner, stranger king?
Are there traditional relations/alliances with one or more neighbouring groups?
Comment: Trade relations with Larantuka, Sika, Boru; barter exchange of rice and corn

Feature: Is there a special name for this alliance?
Is namesake ritually marked, or with features reminiscent of particular kinship relations?
Comment: after 1 month, by the parents
Possible Values: 10:Given Abui name upon birth given by  parents;0:No;1:Yes

Feature: Do descent groups own sets of personal names?
Comment: first name is free, second name is the father's name if he has paid bridewealth already; if not then the second name is the mothers.

Feature: Are names taken from the father's group?
Comment: If the bridewealth is paid

Feature: Are names taken from the mother's group?
Comment: If the bridewealth is not paid

Feature: Are there name taboos?
Are there particular relations not to be addressed, or mentioned, by name
did your language (or a group of people defined by speaking the language) traditionally have a name, other than a locality name
Comment: Ami Hewat Lewo Rotan, Ami Gui Nata Guhar.

Feature: Is there a special word to refer to a foreigner?
Comment: bleka
